{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3528579,"name":"","username":"ilgalith","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/9fc29f/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-16T08:25:19.347Z","cooked":"

Hello, this year our team decided to use Kraken motors on most of our systems, but we could not decide what connectors to use. Since the kraken comes with a 10 AWG cable out of the box, we don’t want to modify that cable much. The connectors that came to our mind were XT60’s and XT90’s. If we were to use XT60’s, we would need to solder a little piece of 12 AWG cable to the end of the 10 AWG cable of the kraken’s but if we were to use XT90 connectors, they would be significantly bulkier on the robot with already very limited space for electronics. And as for crimped connectors, we have absolutely no experience with them. What are your thoughts, can XT60 connectors handle the current need of Kraken motors?

I would recommend 2 options to avoid soldering

  1. Use Andersons with the 45A crimp that supports 10AWG
  2. You can create your own wires with the ring terminals. CTRE sells the ring terminals.
ilgalith:

And as for crimped connectors, we have absolutely no experience with them.

Crimping is very simple and there is a bunch or resources online of how to crimp Andersons and/or Ring terminals

I suspect that I am in the minority on this forum, but I highly recommend these:

amazon.com

Amazon.com: Wago 221-612 Lever-Nuts 10AWG 2 Conductor Compact Wire Connectors 10...

New 10AWG version of popular Wago 221 series Lever-Nuts. If you don't need 10AWG please see 221-412 version. Connect any combination of solid, stranded, and flexible copper wires faster and more reliably. Terminates 20-10 AWG solid and stranded. 2...

They fit the 10AWG wires nicely, have a very tight grip on the wires, have a low resistance, are transparent so that you can look inside to ensure that the wires are seated correctly, only take a few seconds to install, are many-times reusable, and don’t require any special tools other than a wire stripper. They generally won’t accidentally pop open but we wrap ours in electrical tape on the final robot to make sure.

The one downside to them is that the wires come out the same direction as they come in. I’d prefer it if there was a 180 degree of this, but unfortunately Wago only makes a 360 version for this gauge wire.
